docs.lead_paragraph: Representative Gary A. Condit's first public comments about the disappearance of Chandra Ann Levy did not change any minds in the Cullors household. Mark Cullors still believes Mr. Condit has the right not to answer every news media question; Pamela Cullors still thinks Mr. Condit is hiding something. ''I wanted to know, 'Did you have an affair with Chandra?' '' said Ms. Cullors, 51, a human resources director for a food distributing company. ''I think it's morally wrong. It matters to me as a voter, and it matters to me as a wife.''

headline.main: In Condit's District, Few Seem Swayed by Interview

docs.abstract: Few constituents in Repr Gary A Condit's home congressional district are seen swayed by his nationally televised interview on subject of Chandra Ann Levy's disappearance; many people who have voted for him say they are surprised that someone known as upstanding and friendly could suddenly become so cagey; some who voted for Condit say they will not vote for him again; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Representative Gary A. Condit's first public comments about the disappearance of Chandra Ann Levy did not change any minds in the Cullors household. Mark Cullors still believes Mr. Condit has the right not to answer every news media question; Pamela...

docs.lead_paragraph: To: Mitch Daniels, Office of Management and Budget Dear Mitch:
docs.abstract: Op-Ed column by Paul Krugman, in form of open letter to Mitch Daniels of Office of Management and Budget; says Daniels' claim that budget surplus has vanished because of Congressional big spending is bogus; notes that International Monetary Fund's recent report points out that Pres Bush's $1.35 trillion tax cut will actually cost at least $2.5 trillion; says fact is that money that was supposed to be accumulated to pay retirement benefits will be used instead to provide big tax cuts to very, very affluent (M)
docs.snippet: To: Mitch Daniels, Office of Management and Budget    Dear Mitch:

docs.lead_paragraph: Abbott Laboratories, Novartis A.G. and Tyco International Ltd. said today that they were among the targets of a federal investigation of businesses that sell products used to feed critically ill patients through tubes. The Chicago Tribune earlier reported that federal prosecutors are investigating whether Abbott and other makers of medical devices sold pumps and other supplies at discounts to hospitals and nursing homes and then encouraged them to bill the Medicare and Medicaid insurance programs at a higher price.
docs.abstract: Abbott Laboratories, Novartis AG, Zevex International Inc and Tyco International Ltd are among targets of federal investigation of businesses that sell products used to feed critically ill patients through tubes; probe centers around possible fraudulent billing of government healthcare programs (M)
docs.snippet: Abbott Laboratories, Novartis A.G. and Tyco International Ltd. said today that they were among the targets of a federal  investigation of businesses that sell products used to feed critically ill patients through tubes.    The Chicago Tribune earlier...

docs.lead_paragraph: Walter Engel laid down a streak of deep red acrylic paint, then paused to examine his canvas, gold and yellow splotched with red geometric shapes. ''This is what gives me satisfaction,'' he said. To make one sweep of color or to say those six words, Mr. Engel, 45, must execute a painstaking feat of physical effort and mental concentration. Since suffering a stroke almost 12 years ago, he has been able to move only his eyebrows, eyelids and the little finger of his left hand.

headline.main: Art Overcomes a Disability; Speaking With Eyes and Painting With a Wheelchair

docs.abstract: Article on Walter Engel, who was paralyzed by stroke nearly 12 years ago but is able to produce works of abstract art by manipulating his wheelchair over canvas; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Walter Engel laid down a streak of deep red acrylic paint, then paused to examine his canvas, gold and yellow splotched with red geometric shapes. ''This is what gives me satisfaction,'' he said.    To make one sweep of color or to say those six...

docs.lead_paragraph: It was only two years ago that Tennessee was considered a model of good financial management, one of only nine states whose governments had top-drawer credit ratings from all the rating agencies and the envy of Southeastern states struggling to modernize. But that was before a slowing economy gutted its revenue, which was vulnerable because of an almost total reliance on the volatile sales tax. Now Tennessee's fiscal reputation has fallen even further than those of the large group of other states struggling to balance their budgets, and deep rifts have been exposed among residents and legislators over the proper role of state government in lean times.

headline.main: Tennessee's Fiscal Troubles Grow After Futile Push for Income Tax

docs.abstract: Tennessee, once considered model of good financial management, sees its fiscal reputation plummet as it struggles to balance its budget and as rifts arise among residents and legislators over proper role of state government in lean times; at issue is state's reliance on sales tax, which accounts for three-fourths of state's revenue, and its rejection of income tax; as economy slows, sales tax collections drop; opponents of income tax say sales tax would be adequate if state simply cuts back on spending for social purposes; Tennessee is one of only nine states that do not tax personal income; state's aversion to income tax dates from 1931, when Tennessee Supreme Court ruled that income tax enacted not long before was unconstitutional; State Constitution does not specifically prohibit personal income tax, but neither does it list one among several taxes it says state can levy; photos; chart (M)
docs.snippet: It was only two years ago that Tennessee was considered a model of good financial management, one of only nine states whose governments had top-drawer credit ratings from all the rating agencies and the envy of Southeastern states struggling to...

docs.lead_paragraph: Colonoscopy proved far superior to two other common tests for colon cancer in a study that could put pressure on more insurance companies to cover colonoscopy, an expensive screening method. Government researchers found that the two most widely used tests for colon cancer together missed one-quarter of the tumors and precancerous growths detected by colonoscopy.

headline.main: Study Rates Colonoscopy as Far Superior Test

docs.abstract: Colonoscopy proves far superior to two other common tests for colon cancer in study that could put pressure on more insurance companies to cover colonoscopy, an expensive screening method; government researchers find that two most widely used tests for colon cancer, testing for blood in patient's stool and sigmoidoscopy, together miss one-quarter of tumors and precancerous growths detected by colonoscopy; colon cancer is nation's No 2 killer (M)
docs.snippet: Colonoscopy proved far superior to two other common tests for colon cancer in a study that could put pressure on more insurance companies to cover colonoscopy, an expensive screening method.    Government researchers found that the two most widely...

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-11 U.S. Envoy Says Russia Has Time in Missile Talks Under Secretary of State John R. Bolton said in Moscow that ''a vast open space'' still existed for Russia and the United States to agree on joint development of a limited defense system against ballistic missiles, but that the time for reaching such an accord was running out. Mr. Bolton denied that he had issued an unofficial deadline of November for reaching an agreement. He repeated the White House's insistence that it would exercise its right to withdraw from the 1972 ABM Treaty ''at some point,'' unless Moscow agreed to a new arms-control framework. A8 Wariness in Macedonia NATO said it would send 3,500 troops over the next two weeks to collect weapons from ethnic Albanian guerrillas, but it also acknowledged the deep skepticism among the majority Macedonian Slavs, who say they do not believe the rebels will give up all their arms and fear that NATO will become a permanent presence. A8

docs.lead_paragraph: Shares in the medical supply company PolyMedica Corporation fell 26 percent as F.B.I. agents began a second day of searching the main Florida office of the company, which makes diabetes test kits, officials said. On Tuesday, more than 60 agents raided several Florida offices of the company's Liberty Medical Supply unit, executing search warrants.

headline.main: PolyMedica Shares Down After F.B.I. Raid

docs.abstract: Shares of PolyMedica Corp fall 26 percent as FBI agents begin second day of searching main Florida office of company, which makes diabetes test kits; company says payments received by its Liberty Medical unit from Medicare are being investigated (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: One hears so much about Social Security and its problems (''Fabricating a Crisis,'' by Paul Krugman, column, Aug. 21) that it's difficult to credit anyone. Looming boomers, waning workers, greedy Streeters and droll pols all argue over what is necessary to maintain the system at its present level over the long term. That is not the right question.
docs.abstract: Joseph Chianese letter, commenting on Paul Krugman's August 21 Op-Ed column, say one hears so much about Social Security and its problems that it is difficult to credit anyone; says real question is why richest country in world will not take better care of its citizens
